faq.title: Common Concerns
faq.subtitle: Real questions from skeptical engineers (we get it)

concerns.question: Wait, Caro runs locally. How does it stay updated with new dangerous patterns?
concerns.answer: Caro's safety patterns are baked into the binaryâ€”no network needed. When you update Caro (cargo install caro --force), you get the latest patterns. The core dangerous commands (rm -rf /, fork bombs, disk wipers) don't change. We also accept pattern contributions via GitHub.

concerns.question: Will this slow down my incident response?
concerns.answer: No. Caro adds <100ms to command generation. The safety check is instant (pattern matching, not AI inference). In a real incident, that's 100ms that might save you from making things 10x worse. The validation is synchronousâ€”you see the warning immediately.

concerns.question: How does it know my specific system setup (BSD vs GNU, etc.)?
concerns.answer: Caro detects your OS and shell at runtime. On macOS, it knows you're using BSD tools. On Linux, it adjusts for GNU syntax. It reads your $SHELL and adjusts accordingly. No configuration neededâ€”it just works.

concerns.question: What if I actually NEED to run a dangerous command?
concerns.answer: Caro warns, it doesn't jail. When you see a warning, you can still proceedâ€”we just make sure you're doing it intentionally. For truly destructive commands (rm -rf /), you'll need to confirm. This is your seatbelt, not a straitjacket.

concerns.question: Is this just another AI wrapper that sends my commands to the cloud?
concerns.answer: No. Caro runs 100% locally. Your commands, file paths, server names, and directory structures never leave your machine. The inference happens on your hardware. We have zero telemetry. Check the source codeâ€”it's AGPL-3.0 licensed.

concerns.question: Why should I trust AI-generated shell commands at all?
concerns.answer: You shouldn't trust them blindlyâ€”that's the point. Caro generates commands AND validates them before you run them. It's not 'trust the AI'â€”it's 'trust the pattern-based safety layer that catches what the AI might get wrong.' The validation is deterministic, not probabilistic.
